newsitem.title: CANADA: Impoverished children spark outcry in Canada.
newsitem.headline: Impoverished children spark outcry in Canada.

text.p: A new report showing almost a million Canadian children are living in poverty has prompted calls for a child support program similar to the country's plan for senior citizens.

One in five Canadian children, or 800,000, live in poverty, according to a report released Monday by the organization. Statistics Canada defines any family of three with less than $25,000 in income as "poor."

"We need a special fund to protect money from being diverted from children's programs to other national priorities," said Rosemarie Popham, coordinator of Campaign 2000, a coalition of Canadian community groups. "Everyone would pay into the fund, and it would have universal benefits."
Popham said a "small" increase in personal and corporate income taxes would be required to keep the fund going. "You can not address the problem of child poverty without spending money," Popham said.
The federal government currently spends approximately $5 billion each year on income security programs for children.
But the current Liberal government has slashed social spending in the last three years and shows no willingness to raise taxes to finance new programs.
Finance Minister Paul Martin has said that poor children would be his priority if not for the country's deficit problems.
